question_answer_pairs.question: What will happen in case of an upward change in terms of investment in plant and machinery or equipment or turnover or both, and consequent re-classification of an enterprise?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The enterprise will maintain its prevailing status till expiry of one year from the close of the year of registration.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: In case of reverse-graduation of an enterprise, whether as a result of re-classification or due to actual changes in investment in plant and machinery or equipment or turnover or both, and whether the enterprise is registered under the Act or not, will the enterprise continue in its present category till the closure of the financial year?
question_answer_pairs.answer: Yes, the enterprise will be given the benefit of the changed status only with effect from 1st April of the financial year following the year in which such change took place.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What is the date of the Ministry of Finance, Dept
question_answer_pairs.answer: The circular is dated 28th July, 2011.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: According to the circular, what is the criterion for seeking relaxation?
question_answer_pairs.answer: Availability of lower fare is the criterion for seeking relaxation.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What is the policy regarding non-availability of seats in Executive Class?
question_answer_pairs.answer: Non-availability of seats in Executive Class would not entail grant of relaxation and the journey has to be performed in Economy Class.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: For what reasons can relaxation be sought according to the circular?
question_answer_pairs.answer: Relaxation can be sought on the ground of attending meeting or a particular time, or attending meeting notice and approved tour programme.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What is the requirement for foreign travel cases where full or partial grants are received?
question_answer_pairs.answer: For foreign travel cases where full or partial grants are received, the journey has to be performed on Air India up to the place upto which Air India is available and seek relaxation to the remaining sector.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What is the requirement regarding adherence to the approved route for international sectors?
question_answer_pairs.answer: Adherence to the approved route list on international sectors must be observed.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What is the policy regarding reimbursement of fixed amount like air passage fare, land class AC rail fare etc
question_answer_pairs.answer: Cases involving fixed amount of reimbursement like air passage fare, land class AC rail fare etc. need not be referred to Ministry of Civil Aviation.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: Where should the requests for relaxation for Air India tickets purchased from unauthorized agents be forwarded to?
question_answer_pairs.answer: Requests duly forwarded by Dept. Head, may be directly referred to Under Secretary, E-IV Section, Ministry of Finance, Dept. of Expenditure, North Block, New Delhi.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What is the policy regarding non-receipt of approval by the stipulated date?
question_answer_pairs.answer: Non-receipt of approval by the stipulated date does not entitle one to claim relaxation as a matter of right.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What is the policy regarding availability of Air India flights for foreign travel?
question_answer_pairs.answer: For foreign travel cases, where full or partial grants are received, the journey has to be performed on Air India up to the place upto which Air India is available.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What is the policy regarding seeking relaxation on the ground of attending meeting or a particular time?
question_answer_pairs.answer: Those seeking relaxation on the ground of attending meeting or a particular time, must attach meeting notice and approved tour programme.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What is the policy regarding seeking relaxation for travel by airlines other than Air India?
question_answer_pairs.answer: On international routes, where Air India is available, relaxation to travel by other airlines will not be considered.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What is the maximum USD equivalent per exchange that persons resident in India and FPIs can take positions (long or short) without having to establish the existence of any underlying exposure?
question_answer_pairs.answer: Upto USD 5 million equivalent per exchange without having to establish the existence of any underlying exposure.\n\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What has been decided to permit persons resident in India and FPIs to take positions (long or short)?
question_answer_pairs.answer: It has now been decided to permit persons resident in India and FPIs to take positions (long or short), without having to establish the existence of underlying exposure, up to a single limit of USD 100 million equivalent across all currency pairs involving INR, put together, and combined across all exchanges.\n\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What is the onus of the participant in the ETCD market in case of any contravention?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The onus of complying with the provisions of this circular rests with the participant in the ETCD market and in case of any contravention the participant shall be liable to any action that may be warranted as per the provisions of Foreign Exchange Management Act, 1999 and the regulations, directions, etc. issued thereunder.\n\n

question_answer_pairs.question: Who will monitor the limits and breaches, if any, as per this circular?
question_answer_pairs.answer: These limits shall also be monitored by the exchanges, and breaches, if any, may be reported to the Reserve Bank of India.\n\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What other operational guidelines, terms and conditions shall remain unchanged?
question_answer_pairs.answer: All other operational guidelines, terms and conditions shall remain unchanged.\n\n

question_answer_pairs.question: Under which sections of the Foreign Exchange Management Act, 1999 has this circular been issued?
question_answer_pairs.answer: This circular has been issued under Sections 10(4) and 11(1) of the Foreign Exchange Management Act, 1999 (42 of 1999) and is without prejudice to permissions/approvals, if any, required under any other law.\n\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What is the title of the document?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The title of the document is \"NOTIFICATION\".\n

question_answer_pairs.question: Which ministry issued this notification?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The notification was issued by the MINISTRY OF FINANCE (DEPARTMENT OF FINANCIAL SERVICES).\n

question_answer_pairs.question: Where is the notification from?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The notification is from NEW DELHI.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: When was the notification issued?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The notification was issued on THE 26th AUGUST, 2015.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: Under which act is this notification issued?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The notification is issued under the Negotiable Instruments Act, 1881 (26 of 1881).\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What power is the Central Government exercising in this notification?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The Central Government is declaring the second and the fourth Saturday of every month as public holiday for banks in India.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: Which banks are included in this notification?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The banks included in this notification are those that are included in the Second Schedule to the Reserve Bank of India Act, 1934 (2 of 1934).\n

question_answer_pairs.question: When does this notification take effect from?
question_answer_pairs.answer: This notification takes effect from the 1st day of September, 2015.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: Who is the signatory of this notification?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The notification is signed by (Mohammed Mustafa), Joint Secretary to the Government of India.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: To whom is this notification addressed?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The notification is addressed to The Manager, Government of India Press, Ring Road, Mayapuri, New Delhi-110064.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What is the file number of this notification?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The file number of this notification is [F. No. 4/1/7/2015-IR].\n

question_answer_pairs.question: Which act is mentioned in this notification?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The Negotiable Instruments Act, 1881 and the Reserve Bank of India Act, 1934 are mentioned in this notification.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What is the section number mentioned in this notification?
question_answer_pairs.answer: Section 25 of the Negotiable Instruments Act, 1881 is mentioned in this notification.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: Which sub-section is mentioned in this notification?
question_answer_pairs.answer: Sub-section (ii) of Section 3 is mentioned in this notification.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What is the part and section mentioned in this notification?
question_answer_pairs.answer: Part II, Section 3 is mentioned in this notification.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: Where will this notification be published?
question_answer_pairs.answer: This notification will be published in the Gazette of India, Extra ordinary.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What is the purpose of this notification?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The purpose of this notification is to declare the second and the fourth Saturday of every month as public holiday for banks in India, whether or not such banks are included in the Second Schedule to the Reserve Bank of India Act, 1934.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: When will this notification take effect from?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The notification will take effect from the 1st day of September, 2015.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: Who is the issuing authority of this notification?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The issuing authority of this notification is the Joint Secretary to the Government of India.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What is the name of the Joint Secretary who issued this notification?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The name of the Joint Secretary who issued this notification is Mohammed Mustafa.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What does the notification declare?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The Central Government hereby declares the second and the fourth Saturday of every month as public holiday for banks in India, whether or not such banks are included in the Second Schedule to the Reserve Bank of India Act, 1934 (2 of 1934), with effect from the 1st day of September, 2015.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: Which section of the Gazette of India is this notification published in?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The notification is to be published in the Gazette of India, Extra ordinary, Part II, Section 3, Sub-section (ii).\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What are the 10 cluster areas mentioned in the image?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The 10 cluster areas mentioned are West Bengal, Haldia (West Bengal), Howrah (West Bengal), Visakhapatnam (Andhra Pradesh) and Kanpur (UP).\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What is the trend observed in the CEPI scores of the mentioned areas?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The CEPI scores have shown a decreasing trend as compared to the CEPI scores assessed by CPCB in 2011.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What is the purpose of the re-assessment of CEPI scores and taking into consideration that action plans for improving environment quality?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The purpose is to yield results, and it has been decided to lift the moratorium on consideration of proposals for environmental clearance in respect of projects to be located in the above mentioned 10 cluster areas.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What are the four actions mentioned that SPCB needs to ensure?
question_answer_pairs.answer: i) That any new project / activity or any expansion or modernization of existing project or activity or any change in product mix is in line with the overall approved action plan of the CEPI. ii) The implementation of action plan of every CPA to be reviewed by the concerned Chairman, SPCB on quarterly basis and report sent to CPCB by the 7th day of the month. iii) Monitoring in CPAs be got done by SPCB through a third party on annual basis for computing CEPI and the monitoring be done during December-February and the report sent to CPCB by April. CPCB, in turn, to submit its report to MoEF. iv) Monitoring in CEPI be got done by CPCB through a third party on biennial basis for computing CEPI and report submitted to MoEF for taking an appropriate view.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What is the notice given by CPCB regarding the CEPI index in CPA?
question_answer_pairs.answer: If at any time it comes to the notice of CPCB that action plan as implemented properly or the CEPI index in CPA is showing an increasing trend, it will immediately view the matter which may include re-imposition of moratorium.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What are the 10 cluster areas mentioned in the image?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The 10 cluster areas mentioned are West Bengal, Haldia (West Bengal), Howrah (West Bengal), Visakhapatnam (Andhra Pradesh) and Kanpur (UP).\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What is the trend observed in the CEPI scores of the mentioned areas?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The CEPI scores have shown a decreasing trend as compared to the CEPI scores assessed by CPCB in 2011.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What is the purpose of the re-assessment of CEPI scores and taking into consideration that action plans for improving environment quality?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The purpose is to yield results, and it has been decided to lift the moratorium on consideration of proposals for environmental clearance in respect of projects to be located in the above mentioned 10 cluster areas.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What are the four actions mentioned that SPCB needs to ensure?
question_answer_pairs.answer: i) That any new project / activity or any expansion or modernization of existing project or activity or any change in product mix is in line with the overall approved action plan of the CEPI. ii) The implementation of action plan of every CPA to be reviewed by the concerned Chairman, SPCB on quarterly basis and report sent to CPCB by the 7th day of the month. iii) Monitoring in CPAs be got done by SPCB through a third party on annual basis for computing CEPI. iv) Monitoring in CEPI be got done by CPCB through a third party on biennial basis for computing CEPI and report submitted to MoEF.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What are the seven remaining CPAs mentioned in the image?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The seven remaining CPAs are Ankleshwar (Maharashtra), Vapi (Gujarat), Chandrapur (Maharashtra), Vishakhapatnam, Korba (Chhattisgarh), Nagaram Drain Basin (UT) and Dhanbad (Jharkhand).\n

question_answer_pairs.question: Who has given the approval for the issues mentioned in the image?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The issues have been approved by the Competent Authority.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: Who is the Director mentioned in the image?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The Director mentioned is Dr. P.B. Rastogi.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: To whom is the letter addressed?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The letter is addressed to All the Officers of IA Division, Chairpersons / Member Secretaries of all the SEIAAs/SEACs, Chairman, CPCB, and Chairpersons/Member Secretaries of all SPCBs /UTPCCs.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What are the 6 items mentioned in the \"Copy to\" section?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The 6 items are: 1) PS to MEF, 2) PPS to Secretary (E&F), 3) PPS to SS, 4) PPS to JS, 5) Website, MoEF, and 6) Guard File.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What is the purpose of the letter?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The purpose is to ensure that any new project / activity or any expansion or modernization of existing project or activity or any change in product mix is in line with the overall approved action plan of the CEPI.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What is the timeline for the implementation of the action plan of every CPA?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The implementation of the action plan of every CPA is to be reviewed by the concerned Chairman, SPCB on quarterly basis and report sent to CPCB by the 7th day of the month.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: How will the monitoring in CPAs be done?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The monitoring in CPAs will be got done by SPCB through a third party on annual basis for computing CEPI.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: How will the monitoring in CEPI be done?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The monitoring in CEPI will be got done by CPCB through a third party on biennial basis for computing CEPI and report submitted to MoEF.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What will CPCB do if the action plan as per CEPI is not being implemented properly or the CEPI index in CPA is showing an increasing trend?
question_answer_pairs.answer: CPCB will immediately view in the matter which may include re-imposition of moratorium.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What are the seven remaining CPAs that will continue to further orders?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The seven remaining CPAs are Ankleshwar (Maharashtra), Vapi (Gujarat), Chandrapur (Maharashtra), Vishakhapatnam, Korba (Chhattisgarh), Nagaram Drain Basin (UT) and Dhanbad (Jharkhand).

question_answer_pairs.question: What is the purpose of the document?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The document provides instructions and guidelines for inter-unit remittance transfers between Prasar Bharati units.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What types of transfers are mentioned in the document?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The document mentions online transfers using NEFT/RTGS as acceptable modes of inter-unit remittance transfers.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What should the fund receiving unit ensure when receiving transferred funds?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The fund receiving unit should ensure that the funds received by the other units have been correctly accounted for.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What should be done in case of any other similar transaction which is not covered above?
question_answer_pairs.answer: In case of any other similar transaction which is not covered above, clarification may be sought from the finance wings of the respective directorates or from B&A wing of Prasar Bharati Secretariat.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What is the purpose of the instructions given in the document?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The instructions are given to avoid reconciliation and adverse comments of the CAG Audit, and to ensure the DDOs are requested to ensure to book the Remittance transactions cautiously.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: Who is the issuing authority of this document?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The document is issued by the Dy. Director General (B&A), CK Jain.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What are the different units mentioned in the document?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The document mentions \"Prasar Bharati units\" as the units involved in the inter-unit remittance transfers.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What are the two remittance entries that should be there in a transaction?
question_answer_pairs.answer: There should be two remittance entries of a transaction - one by the transferring unit and the other by the receiving unit.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What should the transferring unit ensure when making a transfer?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The transferring unit should ensure that the fund receiving unit will not receive such fund transferred in the remittance heads but to show as \"Commercial Receipts\".\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What is the purpose of the reconciliation mentioned in the document?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The reconciliation is done to ensure that the funds received by the other units have been correctly accounted for.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What are the different directorates mentioned in the document?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The document mentions the Finance Wings of both the Directorates and the ADG (Fin), AIR/ADG (Fin), DD ADG (NABM)/CE (Civil)/ADG (Central Archives).\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What is the purpose of circulating this circular?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The purpose is to ensure strict compliance in reporting such transactions in R&P accounts of all DDOs.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What are the different modes of online transfers mentioned in the document?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The document mentions NEFT/RTGS as the online transfer modes that may be used for inter-unit remittance transfers.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What should the transferring unit do when making a transfer?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The transferring unit should make a minus entry in the head of Commercial Head only to ensure that the fund receiving unit will not receive such fund transferred.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What should the fund receiving unit do when receiving transferred funds?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The fund receiving unit should show the received funds as \"Commercial Receipts\" and not receive them in the remittance heads.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What is the purpose of the two remittance entries in a transaction?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The two remittance entries are to ensure that the funds received by the other unit have been correctly accounted for.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What is the purpose of the reconciliation mentioned in case of any other similar transaction?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The reconciliation is done to ensure that the funds received have been correctly accounted for and to avoid errors in reporting such transactions.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What are the different accounts mentioned where the transactions should be reported?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The transactions should be reported in the R&P accounts of all DDOs.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What is the purpose of the instructions given to the DDOs?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The instructions are given to the DDOs to ensure that the Remittance transactions are booked cautiously to avoid reconciliation and adverse comments of the CAG Audit.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What is the purpose of the circular being circulated?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The circular is being circulated to ensure strict compliance in reporting such transactions in R&P accounts of all DDOs.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What is the role of the Finance Wings of the Directorates mentioned?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The Finance Wings of the Directorates are requested to circulate this circular to ensure strict compliance in reporting such transactions.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What is the purpose of the instructions given regarding the Remittance Heads?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The instructions are given to ensure that the funds received by the other units are not shown in the Remittance Heads but as \"Commercial Receipts\".\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What is the purpose of the reconciliation mentioned in the document?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The reconciliation is done to ensure that a balance is created which needs to be reconciled in case of any other similar transaction.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What are the different types of units mentioned in the document?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The document mentions \"Prasar Bharati units\" as the units involved in the inter-unit remittance transfers.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What is the purpose of the instructions given to the fund receiving unit?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The instructions are given to the fund receiving unit to ensure that the funds received by the other units have been correctly accounted for.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What is the purpose of the instructions given to avoid errors in reporting such transactions?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The instructions are given to avoid errors in reporting such transactions in books of accounts.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What are the different transfer modes mentioned in the document?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The document mentions online transfers using NEFT/RTGS as acceptable modes of inter-unit remittance transfers.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What is the purpose of the circular being issued by the Dy
question_answer_pairs.answer: The circular is issued to provide instructions and guidelines for inter-unit remittance transfers between Prasar Bharati units.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What should the transferring unit do to ensure the fund receiving unit does not receive the transferred funds?

question_answer_pairs.question: What should health care professionals monitor in patients regularly?
question_answer_pairs.answer: Pulmonary symptoms indicative of interstitial lung disease (ILD) and/or pneumonitis.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What types of symptoms may include hypoxia, cough, dyspnea, or radiological changes?
question_answer_pairs.answer: Signs and symptoms may include hypoxia, cough, dyspnea, or radiological changes.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What conditions have been excluded?
question_answer_pairs.answer: Patients with severe ILD and/or pneumonitis.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What treatment should be interrupted in patients?
question_answer_pairs.answer: Interrupt CDK 4/6 inhibitor treatment in patients.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What should patients with severe ILD and/or pneumonitis permanently discontinue?
question_answer_pairs.answer: Permanently discontinue treatment in patients with severe ILD and/or pneumonitis.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What has the FDA reviewed regarding CDK 4/6 inhibitors?
question_answer_pairs.answer: FDA has reviewed CDK 4/6 inhibitors cases from completed and ongoing clinical trials.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What types of lung inflammation have been described in specific types of drug cases?
question_answer_pairs.answer: Interstitial lung disease and pneumonitis.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What were there reports of across the entire drug class, including fatalities?
question_answer_pairs.answer: Serious cases, including fatalities.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What will happen if the project has already been granted EC?
question_answer_pairs.answer: If a proposal for prescribing TORs / grant of EC is received involving land in part or in full for which EC has already been granted to some other project, in such a situation the proposal so received for TOR/EC will be kept on hold.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What will be done if the project involves common land where one of the project has already been granted EC?
question_answer_pairs.answer: A communication will be sent to the Chief Secretary of the concerned State where the project(s) is located, requesting the State Government for specific comments on various contentions made and consequent advice in the matter.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What will happen after the communication is sent to the Chief Secretary?
question_answer_pairs.answer: Separately, a communication will also be sent to the proponent(s) to whom the EC has already been issued, informing about the claim of the land made by the other proponent(s) and mentioning that any further implementation of the project will need to be at the precise location and the boundaries of the plot for which EC had been applied for and in case of any change, EC would need to be amended.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: Who will be the project proponent only after a formal advice is received regarding the land from the State Government?
question_answer_pairs.answer: Only after a formal advice is received regarding the land from the State Government, will be considered appropriate action will be taken in respect of the proposal(s) for which EC has already been granted.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What will happen to the project implementation at this juncture?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The project implementation at this juncture would also be at the risk and cost of the project proponent.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What will be done if a formal advice is received regarding the land from the State Government?
question_answer_pairs.answer: Only after a formal advice is received regarding the land from the State Government, will be considered appropriate action will be taken in respect of the proposal(s) for which EC has already been granted.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: Who will consider the appropriate action to be taken?
question_answer_pairs.answer: Only after a formal advice is received regarding the land from the State Government, will be considered appropriate action will be taken in respect of the proposal(s) for which EC has already been granted.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What will happen to the proposal(s) for which EC has already been granted?
question_answer_pairs.answer: Only after a formal advice is received regarding the land from the State Government, will be considered appropriate action will be taken in respect of the proposal(s) for which EC has already been granted.\n

question_answer_pairs.answer: To provide instructions regarding the handling of proposals for prescribing TORs / grant of EC involving land in part or in full for which EC has already been granted to some other project.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What will happen if the project has already been granted EC?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The proposal so received for TOR/EC will be kept on hold.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What will be done after keeping the proposal on hold?
question_answer_pairs.answer: A communication will be sent to the Chief Secretary of the concerned State where the project(s) is located, requesting the State Government for specific comments on various contentions made and consequent advice in the matter.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What will be done separately from the communication to the Chief Secretary?
question_answer_pairs.answer: Separately, a communication will also be sent to the proponent(s) to whom the EC has already been issued, informing about the claim of the land made by the other proponent(s) and mentioning that any further implementation of the project will need to be at the precise location and the boundaries of the plot for which EC had been applied for and in case of any change, EC would need to be amended.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What will happen after the communication is sent to the proponent(s)?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The project implementation at this juncture would also be at the risk and cost of the project proponent.\n

question_answer_pairs.answer: Only after a formal advice is received regarding the land from the State Government, will be considered appropriate action will be taken in respect of the proposal(s) for which EC has already been granted.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What is the net effect of the changes mentioned in the circular on exporters who imported any inputs/capital goods?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The net effect of these changes would be that any exporter who himself/herself imported any inputs/capital goods in terms of notification Nos. 78/2017-Customs and 79/2017-Customs both dated 13th October, 2017 shall be eligible to claim refund of the IGST paid on exports till the date of the issuance of the notification No. 54/2018 - Central Tax dated the 9th October, 2018.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What is the date from which exporters who are importing goods in terms of notification Nos. 78/2017-Customs and 79/2017-Customs would not be eligible for refund of IGST paid on exports?
question_answer_pairs.answer: Exporters who are importing goods in terms of notification Nos. 78/2017-Customs and 79/2017-Customs both dated 13th October, 2017 would not be eligible for refund of IGST paid on exports as provided in the said sub-rule after the issuance of notification No. 54/2018 - Central Tax dated the 9th October, 2018.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What is the date from which exporters receiving capital goods under the EPCG scheme, either through import or domestic procurement, shall continue to be eligible to claim refund of IGST paid on exports?
question_answer_pairs.answer: Exporters receiving capital goods under the EPCG scheme, either through import in terms of notification No. 79/2017-Customs dated 13th October, 2017 or through domestic procurement in terms of notification No. 48/2017-Central Tax, dated 18th October, 2017, shall continue to be eligible to claim refund of IGST paid on exports and would not be hit by the restrictions provided in the said sub-rule.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What is the subject of this document?
question_answer_pairs.answer: Jumping of ships by Indian seafarers on Cruise Ships in ports in USA.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: Who has received several complaints regarding this issue?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The Directorate General of Shipping, Mumbai has received several complaints.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What is the criminal act that some Indian seafarers are accused of?
question_answer_pairs.answer: Jumping of ships by Indian seafarers on Cruise Ships in ports in USA.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What action has the Directorate General of Shipping decided to take?
question_answer_pairs.answer: It has been decided that a formal complaint will be filed with the employer or the approved Recruitment and Placement Services against the seafarers who jumped the ships.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What privilege will be blocked for the seafarers involved in this issue?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The privilege given to the seafarers in the e-governance system of the Directorate General of Shipping will be blocked and the seafarer will not be allowed to use the e-migrant system.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What action will the Shipping Masters take?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The Shipping Masters will be informed to take necessary action for cancelling the seafarers' CDC and the CDC will be cancelled within 24 hours of the receipt of communication by them.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: Where will the seafarers be referred to for cancellation of their seafarers' passports?
question_answer_pairs.answer: They will be referred to the Ministry of External Affairs for cancellation of the seafarers' passports.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What details are the seafarers required to intimate to the Directorate regarding such cases?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The seafarers are required to intimate this Directorate with details of such seafarers for further necessary action accordingly.\n

question_answer_pairs.answer: The Directorate General of Shipping, Mumbai.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What is the meaning of \"sanction\" as mentioned in the document?

question_answer_pairs.question: What is the central excise duty, service tax or wrongly availed CENVAT credit that is discussed in the circular?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The arrears of central excise duty, service tax or wrongly availed CENVAT credit that are discussed in para 3 above, shall, unless recovered under the existing law, be recovered as central tax liability to be paid through the utilization of amounts available in the electronic credit ledger or electronic cash ledger of the registered person.\n\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What is the recovery of interest, penalty and late fee payable as per the circular?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The arrears of interest, penalty and late fee in relation to CENVAT credit wrongly carried forward, arising out of any of the situations discussed in para 3 above, shall be recovered as interest, penalty and late fee of central tax to be paid through the utilization of the amount available in electronic cash ledger of the registered person.\n\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What are the arrears of interest, penalty and late fee in relation to arrears of central excise duty, service tax or wrongly availed CENVAT credit to be paid through?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The arrears of interest, penalty and late fee in relation to arrears of central excise duty, service tax or wrongly availed CENVAT credit thereof under the existing law arising out of any of the situations discussed in para 3 above, shall, unless recovered under the existing law, be recovered as interest, penalty and late fee of central tax to be paid through the utilization of the amount available in the electronic cash ledger of the registered person.\n\n

question_answer_pairs.question: How can the registered person file the Central Excise / Service Tax return for the period prior to 1st July, 2017?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The registered person may file Central Excise / Service Tax return for the period prior to 1st July, 2017 by logging onto www.aces.gov.in and make payment relating to the same through EASIEST portal (eec-easiest.gov.in), as per the practice prevalent for the period prior to the introduction of GST. However, with effect from 1st of April, 2018, the return filing shall continue on www.aces.gov.in but the payment shall be made through the ICEGATE portal.\n\n

question_answer_pairs.question: How can suitable trade notices be issued to publicize the contents of this Circular?
question_answer_pairs.answer: It is requested that suitable trade notices may be issued to publicize the contents of this Circular.\n\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What should be done if there are any difficulties in implementation of this Circular?
question_answer_pairs.answer: If any, in implementation of this Circular may please be brought to the notice of the Board. Hindi version would follow.\n\n

question_answer_pairs.question: Who has issued this Circular?
question_answer_pairs.answer: (Upender Gupta), Commissioner (GST)\n\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What is the purpose of this Circular?
question_answer_pairs.answer: To provide instructions regarding recovery of arrears of central excise duty, service tax or wrongly availed CENVAT credit.\n\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What are the situations discussed in para 3 of the circular?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The situations discussed in para 3 above, where the arrears of central excise duty, service tax or wrongly availed CENVAT credit are to be recovered.\n\n

question_answer_pairs.question: How will the arrears of central excise duty, service tax or wrongly availed CENVAT credit be recovered if not recovered under the existing law?
question_answer_pairs.answer: They shall be recovered as central tax liability to be paid through the utilization of amounts available in the electronic credit ledger or electronic cash ledger of the registered person.\n\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What is the procedure mentioned in para 4
question_answer_pairs.answer: The registered person may file Central Excise / Service Tax return for the period prior to 1st July, 2017 by logging onto www.aces.gov.in and make payment relating to the same through EASIEST portal (eec-easiest.gov.in), as per the practice prevalent for the period prior to the introduction of GST.\n\n

question_answer_pairs.question: How will the recovery of arrears from assessees under the existing law be made in cases where such assessees are not registered under the CGST Act, 2017?
question_answer_pairs.answer: Such arrears shall be recovered in cash, under the provisions of the existing law and the payment of the same shall be made as per the procedure mentioned in para 4.3 above.\n\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What is the deadline for filing the Central Excise / Service Tax return for the period prior to 1st July, 2017?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The registered person may file Central Excise / Service Tax return for the period prior to 1st July, 2017.\n\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What is the portal through which the payment relating to the Central Excise / Service Tax return for the period prior to 1st July, 2017 should be made?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The payment relating to the same shall be made through EASIEST portal (eec-easiest.gov.in), as per the practice prevalent for the period prior to the introduction of GST.\n\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What is the change in the payment portal from 1st April, 2018 onwards?
question_answer_pairs.answer: With effect from 1st of April, 2018, the return filing shall continue on www.aces.gov.in but the payment shall be made through the ICEGATE portal.\n\n

question_answer_pairs.question: Who shall be automatically taken to the payment portal on filing of the return, as per the circular?
question_answer_pairs.answer: As the registered person shall be automatically taken to the payment portal on filing of the return, the user interface remains the same for him.\n\n

question_answer_pairs.answer: Such arrears shall be recovered in cash, under the provisions of the existing law and the payment of the same shall be made as per the procedure mentioned in para 4.3 above.\n\n

question_answer_pairs.answer: The qualification/eligibility requirements are: (i) Be a citizen of India, (ii) Be a Law Graduate, fluent in English (speaking & writing) and having at least 50% marks in Graduation, and have good knowledge of computer operations.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What are the experience requirements for the post?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The experience requirements are: (a) Registrar of the Supreme Court or a High Court in India, or (b) An Advocate with 15 years practice at the Bar, or (c) Secretary of a State Bar Council for at least 7 years, or (d) District Judge having five years experience as District Judge of a recognized Law College having experience as a Principal for ten years and seven years standing at the Bar, or (f) Professor or Reader of Law in University recognized by the Council with 10 years standing and having seven years experience at the Bar, or (g) Law Graduate with five years experience as Joint Secretary and seven years as Assistant Secretary of the Bar Council of India.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What is the age requirement for the post?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The age requirement is between 40 years and not more than 50 years as on 31.7.2015.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What is the pay scale for the post?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The pay scale is PB-4 Rs. 37,400-67,000 plus Grade pay of Rs. 8700.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: How should the application be submitted?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The application should be submitted on plain paper along with attested photograph and attested copies of educational certificates along with a bank draft of Rs. 2000/- (non-refundable) payable in the name of Bar Council of India, New Delhi duly signed by the applicant to be submitted by hand or through registered post to Joint Secretary, Bar Council of India Office, 21, Rouse Avenue, Institutional Area, New Delhi-110002 upto 14th November, 2015.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: Who is the Joint Secretary signing the advertisement?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The Joint Secretary signing the advertisement is Ashok Kumar Pandey.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What is the name of the organization advertising the post?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The organization advertising the post is the Bar Council of India (Statutory Body Constituted under the Advocates Act, 1961).\n

question_answer_pairs.answer: The office of the Bar Council of India is located at 21, Rouse Avenue, Institutional Area, New Delhi-110002.\n

question_answer_pairs.answer: The deadline for submitting the application is 14th November, 2015.\n

question_answer_pairs.answer: The minimum percentage of marks required in graduation is 50%.\n

question_answer_pairs.answer: The required experience as a District Judge is five years.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: How many years of experience as a Principal of a recognized Law College is required?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The required experience as a Principal of a recognized Law College is ten years.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: How many years of standing at the Bar is required for a Professor or Reader of Law?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The required standing at the Bar for a Professor or Reader of Law is seven years.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: How many years of experience as Joint Secretary and Assistant Secretary of the Bar Council of India is required?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The required experience as Joint Secretary and Assistant Secretary of the Bar Council of India is seven years each.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What are the affected product codes?
What are the affected product GTINs?
What is the reason for the recall?
question_answer_pairs.answer: Internal quality data sources have demonstrated that the aforementioned batches may not be performing as intended and may result in false HPV DNA not detected for HPV genotype 31.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What action is being requested?
question_answer_pairs.answer: Roche is requesting customers to discontinue the use of LINEAR ARRAY HPV (Human Papilloma Virus) Genotyping Test.\n
